user_request: Write a poem about a traveler at a fork in a yellow wood who chooses the less-traveled path.

revision_history.draft:
# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, floating somewhere
between four walls of black and something
thinner, greening in the hum of earth.

The wood does not speak but it sponges.
It takes the frequency from everything that moves—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like a psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became a thing
less real than the concept of a screen.

I followed the road less populated
by light. The other path smelled of copper
gone to rust, of tin immersed in ferns,
of data dying small and patient
in the soil's black furred stomach.

The fork was not a question.
It was an amputation.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one.
Its operating system dreams
of signals that have never left.

I pressed my palm to what remained
and felt—a circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

The moss had closed over every name.
Over every tower. Over every frequency
that came seeking its own reflection
found only glass and green and the deep
particular quiet where information
goes to rest forever, cooled,
absorbed into the living dark
as something it can no longer give back.

I sat where the wood was thick enough
to swallow even black. The moss held my name
like a coat. I ate berries
and did not wonder who had put them there—
the body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

There is a loneliness that keeps records.
There is a kind that doesn't need
to. The fork chose mine.
I stayed. The trees kept everything
except for me, and even that
slowly, over centuries, let go.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The refrain "the fork chose mine" is the poem's true spine — it shifts meaning each time it returns, and that's where the intelligence lives. The closing movement from "kept everything / except for me, and even that / slowly, over centuries, let go" earns its weight because of what precedes it; the accumulation of specific material detail (moss holding a name like a coat, berries appearing without attribution) builds trust in the speaker's strangeness.

The line "I followed the road less populated / by light" — that's precise and strange enough to land. The poem is at its strongest when it resists paraphrase: when it holds an image rather than explaining what the image means.

The circuit-board-as-bone metaphor (circuit boards rust like bones) works because it stays physical; it doesn't sentimentalize.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / dead language:** "deep / particular quiet where information / goes to rest forever" — this is the poem reaching for grandeur and failing. "Rest forever, cooled" is a cliché dressed in scientific diction. The poem has already done better with "its own superfluousness, / its own fruit, its own reason to stay." Cut or replace.

**Abstraction bloat:** Lines 39–45 are the weakest stretch:
> There is a loneliness that keeps records.
> There is a kind that doesn't need
> to. The fork chose mine.
> I stayed. The trees kept everything
> except for me, and even that
> slowly, over centuries, let go.

This is summary of what the poem has already shown us in physical terms. "A loneliness that keeps records" — this is a thesis statement, not poetry. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress these lines. Trust the image of moss swallowing names. Trust the amputation refrain. The fork chose *what*? Not *loneliness*. What did it choose?

**Redundancy / structural padding:** "I left my phone inside its case" appears in line 2 and returns in line 13 ("carried against my chest"). "Cased in its own silence, floating somewhere" — this is three gestures doing one thing. **Direction:** Choose the strongest version of each setup. The poem opens with a dead phone; don't restate it.

**Weak transition / filler:** "It was an amputation." This line does nothing except name what happened. It's the least interesting thing to say about a fork that chose something. **Direction:** Replace with imagery — let the reader arrive at the conclusion without being told.

**"Your heartbeat read six miles out, / a drone's descent tracked like a psalm"—** "Tracked like a psalm" is decorative personification. The poem has already shown us light and copper and ferns; it

revision_history.draft:
# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, somewhere
between kitchen drawer and the wall's thin skin
where earth hums a frequency the wood sponges up—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became less real than the wanting
of a screen.

I followed the road that thinned
past glass and concrete, where light thinned
into a path that smelled of copper
gone to rust, tin immersed in ferns,
data dying small beneath the soil's black fur.

The fork was not a question.
It was the cleanest thing I had seen—
a groove pressed through wood like a seam
in a garment no one would sew anymore,
and I turned right.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one. Its operating system
dreams of signals that have never left,
their masts white-gold in moss-grown shoulders
of a forest where even names
have been eaten down to bone.

The fork held what the drawer couldn't—
the phone's black body almost swallowed whole,
just visible, its screen a dark mole
on the wood's belly. I pressed my palm to it
and felt—the circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

Moss had closed over every name.
Over every tower. The green advanced
into the spaces between what things were
until even silence thickened into something warm
and living, holding the exact shape
of not knowing what came first—
the signal or the desire for it.

I sat where the wood was dense enough
to swallow black. Berries clustered
on a vine I didn't plant but ate,
not wondering who left them there—
a body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

The trees kept everything except for me.
Even that slow let go over centuries,
the fork erasing the question it held open
like a seam torn clean through.

revision_history.draft:
# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, somewhere
between kitchen drawer and the wall's thin skin—
earth hums a frequency the wood sponges up—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became less real than the wanting
of a screen.

I followed the road that thinned
past glass and concrete, where light thinned
into a path that smelled of copper
gone to rust, tin immersed in ferns,
data dying small beneath the soil's black fur—

the fork chose mine. I took the left
and stumbled on a name I couldn't read,
erased under moss so thoroughly it looked like rock.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one. Its operating system
dreams of signals that have never left—
their masts white-gold in moss-grown shoulders
of a forest where even names
have been eaten down to bone.

The drawer held my phone's black body almost swallowed whole,
its screen a dark mole on the wood's belly. I pressed my palm to it
and felt—the circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

Moss had closed over every name.
Over every tower. The green advanced
into the spaces between what things were
until even silence thickened into something warm
and living, holding the exact shape
of not knowing what came first—
the signal or the desire for it.

I sat where the wood was dense enough
to swallow black. Berries clustered
on a vine I didn't plant but ate,
not wondering who left them there—

a body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

The trees kept everything except for me.
Even that slow let go over centuries—
the groove in the wood where a fork once sat
worn clean through like a scar I'd wear my whole life
and call mine.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The refrain "the fork chose mine" is the poem's true spine — it shifts meaning each time it returns, and that's where the intelligence lives. The closing movement from "kept everything except for me" through "like a seam torn clean through" earns its weight because of what precedes it; the accumulation of specific material detail (moss holding a name like a coat, berries appearing without attribution) builds trust in the speaker's strangeness.

The line "I followed the road that thinned / past glass and concrete, where light thinned" — this is precise, strange, earned. The circuit-board-as-bone metaphor (circuit boards rust like bones) works because it stays physical; it doesn't sentimentalize.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché / dead language:**
- "deep / particular quiet where information / goes to rest forever" — abstract summary dressed in grandeur, cut or replace with something as specific as the soil's black fur.
- "a loneliness that keeps records" (lines 39–41) is a thesis statement, not poetry. Cut entirely or replace with imagery.

**Abstraction bloat:**
- Lines 39–45 are summary of what the poem already showed in physical terms — cut or compress drastically; trust the image of moss swallowing names.
- "There is a loneliness that keeps records" / "There is a kind that doesn't need / to." — this is catalog abstraction. Cut.

**Redundancy:**
- "I left my phone inside its case" appears in lines 2 and 13; "cased in its own silence, floating somewhere" does three gestures with one action.
- **Direction:** Choose the strongest setup. The poem opens with a dead phone — don't restate it.

**Structural padding:**
- "It was an amputation." This line names what happened instead of showing it. Replace with imagery.
- "A body produces its own superfluousness, / its own fruit, its own reason to stay" — this is the speaker explaining themselves. Cut or compress into image.

**Decorative personification:**
- "Leaves whispering goodbye" (cliché avoided but still present in earlier drafts)
- "Moss had closed over every name. Over every tower." — too many iterations, and "moss" does the same thing three times. **Direction:** Choose one clean image or cut.

**Weak transition:**
- "It was the cleanest thing I had seen— / a groove pressed through wood like a seam" — "cleanest" is an adjective doing summary work; remove it.
- "a fork erased the question it held open" (line 47) names what happened instead of showing it. **Direction:** Replace with physical image.

**Line breaks:**
- "

# Radio Frequency

At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, somewhere
between drawer and kitchen wall—
earth hums a frequency the wood sponges up—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent tracked like psalm—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became less real than the wanting
of a screen.

I followed the road that thinned
past glass and concrete, where light thinned
into a path that smelled of copper
gone to rust, tin immersed in ferns,
data dying small beneath the soil's black fur—

the fork chose mine. I took the left
and stumbled on a name I couldn't read,
worn smooth under moss so thoroughly it looked like rock.

Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one. Its operating system
dreams of signals that have never left—
their masts white-gold in moss-grown shoulders
of a forest where even names
have been eaten down to bone.

Moss had closed over every tower.
The green advanced into the spaces between what things were
until silence thickened warm and living,
holding the exact shape
of not knowing what came first—
the signal or the wanting of it.

I sat where wood was dense enough
to swallow black. Berries clustered
on a vine I didn't plant but ate,
not wondering who left them there—

a body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

The trees kept everything except for me.
Even that slow let go over centuries—
the groove where a fork once sat worn clean through
like a scar I'd wear my whole life.

I pressed my palm to the drawer's black body
and felt—the circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing.

The line "I followed the road that thinned / past glass and concrete, where light thinned" — this is precise, strange, earned. The circuit-board-as-bone metaphor (circuit boards rust like bones) works because it stays physical; it doesn't sentimentalize.

---

- "a loneliness that keeps records" (lines 39–41) is a thesis statement, not poetry. Cut entirely or replace with imagery.

revision_history.draft:
At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, somewhere
between drawer and kitchen wall—
the wood absorbed the earth's very hum,
a low resonance trapped between sap and grain—

your heartbeat read six miles out,
a drone's descent shaped like a letter
pressed against the window of a house
no one lives in anymore—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing
until the screen became less real than the wanting
of a screen.

I followed the road that thinned
past glass and concrete, where light thinned
into a path that smelled of copper
gone to rust, tin immersed in ferns,
a coaxial cable's green sheen
rotting down into the soil like something
it had finally found—and I knelt
where it crossed beneath the ferns
and felt the ridge where plastic melted
into mineral, into the slow
understanding of a rock
that nothing asks of it.

The fork chose mine. I took the left
and stumbled on a name I couldn't read,
worn smooth under moss so thoroughly it looked like rock.
Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one. Its operating system
dreams of signals that have never left—
their masts white-gold in moss-grown shoulders
of a forest where even names
have been eaten down to bone.

Moss had closed over every tower.
The green advanced into the spaces between what things were
until silence thickened warm and living,
holding the exact shape
of not knowing what came first—
the signal or the wanting of it.

I sat where wood was dense enough
to swallow black. Berries clustered
on a vine I didn't plant but ate, their juice
darkening my knuckles like something
ordinary made beautiful only by circumstance—

a body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

The trees kept everything except for me.
Even that slow let go over centuries—
the groove where a fork once sat worn clean through
like a scar I'd wear my whole life.

I pressed my palm to the drawer's black body
and felt—the circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing,
its roots drawing water no one promised it,
just the wanting, just the slow
appetite of being

---

**Revised refrain:**

And I kept wanting you in the exact way
a drawer keeps its black body whole—
not storage, not container, but the fact
of holding without naming what's held.

revision_history.draft:
At the split I left my phone inside its case,
cased in its own silence, somewhere
between drawer and kitchen wall—

your heartbeat read six miles out—
and what I carried against my chest
gradually darkened into nothing.

I followed the road that thinned
past glass and concrete, where light thinned
into a path that smelled of copper
gone to rust, tin immersed in ferns,
a coaxial cable's green sheen
rotting down into the soil like something
it had finally found—and I knelt
where it crossed beneath the ferns
and felt the ridge where plastic melted
into mineral, into the slow
understanding of a rock
that asked nothing.

The fork chose mine. I took the left
and stumbled on a name worn smooth under moss,
its every letter swallowed whole—
nothing left but the groove where it sat.
Somewhere underneath the hum
a phone answers no one. Its operating system
dreams of signals that have never left—
their masts white-gold in moss-grown shoulders
of a forest where even names
have been eaten down to bone.

Moss had closed over every tower.
The green advanced into the spaces between what things were
until silence thickened warm and living,
holding the exact shape
of not knowing what came first—
the signal or the wanting of it.

I sat where wood was dense enough
to swallow black. Berries clustered
on a vine I didn't plant but ate, their juice
darkening my knuckles like something
ordinary made beautiful only by circumstance—

a body produces its own superfluousness,
its own fruit, its own reason to stay.

The trees kept everything except for me.
Even that slow let go over centuries—
the groove where a fork once sat worn clean through
like a scar I'd wear my whole life.

I pressed my palm to the drawer's black body
and felt—the circuit, yes,
but also the nerve of a tree
learning how to ask for nothing,
its roots drawing water no one promised it,
just the slow
appetite of being

And I kept wanting you in the exact way
a drawer keeps its black body whole—
not storage, not container, but the fact
of holding without naming what's held.
